intro: Mariscus scleropodus, commonly known as the rock spurge, is a flowering plant belonging to the Euphorbiaceae family. It is characterized by its succulent, fleshy stems and leaves, which help it retain water in arid environments. The plant produces small, inconspicuous flowers that are typically green or yellowish in color. It is native to regions with rocky or sandy soils, often found in Mediterranean climates. Mariscus scleropodus is adapted to withstand drought and poor soil conditions, making it a resilient species in its native habitat.
